name: imo_2020_p1
informal_prefix: \/--Consider the convex quadrilateral $ABCD$. The point $P$ is in the interior of $ABCD$. The following ratio equalities hold: $\angle PAD : \angle PBA : \angle DPA = 1 : 2 : 3 = \angle CBP : \angle BAP : \angle BPC$. Prove that the following three lines meet in a point: the internal bisectors of angles $\angle ADP$ and $\angle PCB$ and the perpendicular bisector of segment $\overline{AB}$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Consider the convex quadrilateral $ABCD$. The point $P$ is in the interior of $ABCD$. The following ratio equalities hold: $\angle PAD : \angle PBA : \angle DPA = 1 : 2 : 3 = \angle CBP : \angle BAP : \angle BPC$. Prove that the following three lines meet in a point: the internal bisectors of angles $\angle ADP$ and $\angle PCB$ and the perpendicular bisector of segment $\overline{AB}$.-\/
theorem problem_imo_2020_p1:
  ∀ (A B C D P Q R Z X : Point) (AB BC CD DA DQ l CR: Line),
  (formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA) ∧
  (P.sameSide C AB) ∧ (P.sameSide A CD) ∧ (P.sameSide D BC) ∧
  (P.sameSide B DA) ∧ (B ≠ P) ∧ (A ≠ P) ∧ (C ≠ P) ∧ (D ≠ P) ∧
  (2 * (∠P : A : D : ℝ) = (∠P : B : A : ℝ)) ∧
  (3 * (∠P : A : D : ℝ) = (∠D : P : A : ℝ)) ∧
  (2 * (∠C : B : P : ℝ) = (∠C : A : P : ℝ)) ∧
  (3 * (∠C : B : P : ℝ) = (∠B : P : C : ℝ)) ∧
  (∠Q : D : A : ℝ) = (∠Q : D : P : ℝ) ∧
  (∠R : C : B : ℝ) = (∠R : C : B : ℝ) ∧
  (perpBisector A B l) ∧
  (distinctPointsOnLine D Q DQ) ∧
  (distinctPointsOnLine C R CR) →
  concurrent DQ CR l := by
goal:
∀ (A B C D P Q R Z X : Point) (AB BC CD DA DQ l CR: Line),
  (formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA) ∧
  (P.sameSide C AB) ∧ (P.sameSide A CD) ∧ (P.sameSide D BC) ∧
  (P.sameSide B DA) ∧ (B ≠ P) ∧ (A ≠ P) ∧ (C ≠ P) ∧ (D ≠ P) ∧
  (2 * (∠P : A : D : ℝ) = (∠P : B : A : ℝ)) ∧
  (3 * (∠P : A : D : ℝ) = (∠D : P : A : ℝ)) ∧
  (2 * (∠C : B : P : ℝ) = (∠C : A : P : ℝ)) ∧
  (3 * (∠C : B : P : ℝ) = (∠B : P : C : ℝ)) ∧
  (∠Q : D : A : ℝ) = (∠Q : D : P : ℝ) ∧
  (∠R : C : B : ℝ) = (∠R : C : B : ℝ) ∧
  (perpBisector A B l) ∧
  (distinctPointsOnLine D Q DQ) ∧
  (distinctPointsOnLine C R CR) →
  concurrent DQ CR l
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Consider the convex quadrilateral $ABCD$. The point $P$ is in the interior of $ABCD$. The following ratio equalities hold: $\angle PAD : \angle PBA : \angle DPA = 1 : 2 : 3 = \angle CBP : \angle BAP : \angle BPC$. Prove that the following three lines meet in a point: the internal bisectors of angles $\angle ADP$ and $\angle PCB$ and the perpendicular bisector of segment $\overline{AB}$.

name: imo_2021_p3
informal_prefix: \/--Let $D$ be an interior point of the acute triangle $ABC$ with $AB > AC$ so that $\angle DAB= \angle CAD$. The point $E$ on the segment $AC$ satisfies $\angle ADE= \angle BCD$, the point $F$ on the segment $AB$ satisfies $\angle FDA= \angle DBC$, and the point $X$ on the line $AC$ satisfies $CX=BX$. Let $O_1$ and $O_2$ be the circumcentres of the triangles $ADC$ and $EXD$ respectively. Prove that the lines $BC$, $EF$, and $O_1 O_2$ are concurrent.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Let $D$ be an interior point of the acute triangle $ABC$ with $AB > AC$ so that $\angle DAB= \angle CAD$. The point $E$ on the segment $AC$ satisfies $\angle ADE= \angle BCD$, the point $F$ on the segment $AB$ satisfies $\angle FDA= \angle DBC$, and the point $X$ on the line $AC$ satisfies $CX=BX$. Let $O_1$ and $O_2$ be the circumcentres of the triangles $ADC$ and $EXD$ respectively. Prove that the lines $BC$, $EF$, and $O_1 O_2$ are concurrent.-\/
theorem problem_imo_2021_p3: ∀ (A B C D E F X O₁ O₂: Point) (AB BC CA: Line), formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
D.sameSide A BC ∧
D.sameSide C AB ∧
D.sameSide B CA ∧
|(A─B)| > |(A─C)| ∧
E.onLine AC ∧ ∠A:D:E = ∠B:C:D ∧
F.onLine AB ∧ ∠F:D:A = ∠D:B:C ∧
X.onLine AC ∧ |(C─X)| = |(B─X)| ∧
circumCentre O₁ A D C ∧ circumCentre O₂ E X D → concurrent BC EF O₁O₂ := by
goal:
(A B C D E F X O₁ O₂: Point) (AB BC CA: Line), formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
D.sameSide A BC ∧
D.sameSide C AB ∧
D.sameSide B CA ∧
|(A─B)| > |(A─C)| ∧
E.onLine AC ∧ ∠A:D:E = ∠B:C:D ∧
F.onLine AB ∧ ∠F:D:A = ∠D:B:C ∧
X.onLine AC ∧ |(C─X)| = |(B─X)| ∧
circumCentre O₁ A D C ∧ circumCentre O₂ E X D → concurrent BC EF O₁O₂
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Let $D$ be an interior point of the acute triangle $ABC$ with $AB > AC$ so that $\angle DAB= \angle CAD$. The point $E$ on the segment $AC$ satisfies $\angle ADE= \angle BCD$, the point $F$ on the segment $AB$ satisfies $\angle FDA= \angle DBC$, and the point $X$ on the line $AC$ satisfies $CX=BX$. Let $O_1$ and $O_2$ be the circumcentres of the triangles $ADC$ and $EXD$ respectively. Prove that the lines $BC$, $EF$, and $O_1 O_2$ are concurrent.

name: imo_2021_p4
informal_prefix: \/--Let $\Gamma$ be a circle with centre $I$, and $ABCD$ a convex quadrilateral such that each of the segments $AB, BC, CD$ and $DA$ is tangent to $\Gamma$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of the triangle $AIC$. The extension of $BA$ beyond $A$ meets $\Omega$ at $X$, and the extension of $BC$ beyond $C$ meets $\Omega$ at $Z$. The extensions of $AD$ and $CD$ beyond $D$ meet $\Omega$ at $Y$ and $T$, respectively. Prove that \AD + DT + T X + XA = CD + DY + Y Z + ZC\-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Let $\Gamma$ be a circle with centre $I$, and $ABCD$ a convex quadrilateral such that each of the segments $AB, BC, CD$ and $DA$ is tangent to $\Gamma$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of the triangle $AIC$. The extension of $BA$ beyond $A$ meets $\Omega$ at $X$, and the extension of $BC$ beyond $C$ meets $\Omega$ at $Z$. The extensions of $AD$ and $CD$ beyond $D$ meet $\Omega$ at $Y$ and $T$, respectively. Prove that \AD + DT + T X + XA = CD + DY + Y Z + ZC\-\/
theorem problem_imo_2021_p4 : ∀ (A B C D Y T Z X : Point) (AB BC CD DA: Line) (Γ Ω: Circle), formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
tangentLine AB Γ ∧ tangentLine BC Γ ∧ tangentLine CD Γ ∧ tangentLine DA Γ ∧
circumCircle Ω A I C ∧
X.onLine AB ∧ X.onCircle Ω ∧
Z.onLine BC ∧ Z.onCircle Ω ∧
Y.onLine DA ∧ Y.onCircle Ω ∧
T.onLine CD ∧ T.onCircle Ω → |(A─D)| + |(D─T)| + |(T─X)| + |(X─A)| = |(C─D)| + |(D─Y)| + |(Y─Z)| + |(Z─C)|:= by
goal:
∀ (A B C D Y T Z X : Point) (AB BC CD DA: Line) (Γ Ω: Circle), formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
tangentLine AB Γ ∧ tangentLine BC Γ ∧ tangentLine CD Γ ∧ tangentLine DA Γ ∧
circumCircle Ω A I C ∧
X.onLine AB ∧ X.onCircle Ω ∧
Z.onLine BC ∧ Z.onCircle Ω ∧
Y.onLine DA ∧ Y.onCircle Ω ∧
T.onLine CD ∧ T.onCircle Ω → |(A─D)| + |(D─T)| + |(T─X)| + |(X─A)| = |(C─D)| + |(D─Y)| + |(Y─Z)| + |(Z─C)|
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Let $\Gamma$ be a circle with centre $I$, and $ABCD$ a convex quadrilateral such that each of the segments $AB, BC, CD$ and $DA$ is tangent to $\Gamma$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of the triangle $AIC$. The extension of $BA$ beyond $A$ meets $\Omega$ at $X$, and the extension of $BC$ beyond $C$ meets $\Omega$ at $Z$. The extensions of $AD$ and $CD$ beyond $D$ meet $\Omega$ at $Y$ and $T$, respectively. Prove that \AD + DT + T X + XA = CD + DY + Y Z + ZC\

name: imo_2022_p4
informal_prefix: \/--Let $ABCDE$ be a convex pentagon such that $BC = DE$. Assume that there is a point $T$ inside $ABCDE$ with $TB = TD$, $TC = TE$ and $\angle ABT = \angle TEA$. Let line $AB$ intersect lines $CD$ and $CT$ at points $P$ and $Q$, respectively. Assume that the points $P, B, A, Q$ occur on their line in that order. Let line $AE$ intersect lines $CD$ and $DT$ at points $R$ and $S$, respectively. Assume that the points $R, E, A, S$ occur on their line in that order. Prove that the points $P, S, Q, R$ lie on a circle.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Let $ABCDE$ be a convex pentagon such that $BC = DE$. Assume that there is a point $T$ inside $ABCDE$ with $TB = TD$, $TC = TE$ and $\angle ABT = \angle TEA$. Let line $AB$ intersect lines $CD$ and $CT$ at points $P$ and $Q$, respectively. Assume that the points $P, B, A, Q$ occur on their line in that order. Let line $AE$ intersect lines $CD$ and $DT$ at points $R$ and $S$, respectively. Assume that the points $R, E, A, S$ occur on their line in that order. Prove that the points $P, S, Q, R$ lie on a circle.-\/
theorem problem_imo_2022_p4 : ∀ (A B C D T Y T R S: Point) (AB BC CD DE EA EA CT: Line), (formPentagon A B C D E AB BC CD DE EA) ∧
|(T─B)|=|(T─D)| ∧ |(T─C)|=|(T─E)| ∧ |(T─B)|=|(T─D)| ∧ ∠A:B:T = ∠T:E:A ∧
twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CD P ∧ distinctPointsOnLine C T CT ∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CT Q ∧
between P B A ∧ between B A Q ∧
distinctPointsOnLine D T DT ∧
twoLinesIntersectAtPoint CD EA R
∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint DT EA S
∧ between R E A ∧ between E A S
→ cyclic P S Q R := by
goal:
∀ (A B C D T Y T R S: Point) (AB BC CD DE EA EA CT: Line), (formPentagon A B C D E AB BC CD DE EA) ∧
|(T─B)|=|(T─D)| ∧ |(T─C)|=|(T─E)| ∧ |(T─B)|=|(T─D)| ∧ ∠A:B:T = ∠T:E:A ∧
twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CD P ∧ distinctPointsOnLine C T CT ∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CT Q ∧
between P B A ∧ between B A Q ∧
distinctPointsOnLine D T DT ∧
twoLinesIntersectAtPoint CD EA R
∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint DT EA S
∧ between R E A ∧ between E A S
→ cyclic P S Q R
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Let $ABCDE$ be a convex pentagon such that $BC = DE$. Assume that there is a point $T$ inside $ABCDE$ with $TB = TD$, $TC = TE$ and $\angle ABT = \angle TEA$. Let line $AB$ intersect lines $CD$ and $CT$ at points $P$ and $Q$, respectively. Assume that the points $P, B, A, Q$ occur on their line in that order. Let line $AE$ intersect lines $CD$ and $DT$ at points $R$ and $S$, respectively. Assume that the points $R, E, A, S$ occur on their line in that order. Prove that the points $P, S, Q, R$ lie on a circle.

name: imo_2023_p2
informal_prefix: \/--Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with $AB < AC$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of $ABC$. Let $S$ be the midpoint of the arc $CB$ of $\Omega$ containing $A$. The perpendicular from $A$ to $BC$ meets $BS$ at $D$ and meets $\Omega$ again at $E \neq A$. The line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meets line $BE$ at $L$. Denote the circumcircle of triangle $BDL$ by $\omega$. Let $\omega$ meet $\Omega$ again at $P \neq B$. Prove that the line tangent to $\omega$ at $P$ meets line $BS$ on the internal angle bisector of $\angle BAC$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with $AB < AC$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of $ABC$. Let $S$ be the midpoint of the arc $CB$ of $\Omega$ containing $A$. The perpendicular from $A$ to $BC$ meets $BS$ at $D$ and meets $\Omega$ again at $E \neq A$. The line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meets line $BE$ at $L$. Denote the circumcircle of triangle $BDL$ by $\omega$. Let $\omega$ meet $\Omega$ again at $P \neq B$. Prove that the line tangent to $\omega$ at $P$ meets line $BS$ on the internal angle bisector of $\angle BAC$.-\/
theorem problem_imo_2023_p2 : ∀ (A B C D E S L P X: Point) (AB BC CA ADE BE DL l BS: Line) (Ω ω: Circle), formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
|(A─B)| < |(A─C)| ∧ circumCircle Ω A B C ∧
S.onCircle Ω ∧ |(S─C)| = |(S─B)| ∧ S.sameSide A BC
∧ threePointsOnLine A D E ADE ∧ perpLine ADE BC ∧
D.onLine BS ∧ E.onCircle Ω ∧ threePointsOnLine B E L BE ∧
distinctPointsOnLine D L DL ∧ ¬(BE.intersectsLine DL) ∧
circumCircle ω B D L ∧
P.onCircle Ω ∧ P.onCircle ω ∧ P ≠ B ∧
distinctPointsOnLine B S BS ∧
tangentAtPoint l ω P ∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint l BS X
 → ∠ X:A:B = ∠X:A:C := by
goal:
∀ (A B C D E S L P X: Point) (AB BC CA ADE BE DL l BS: Line) (Ω ω: Circle), formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
|(A─B)| < |(A─C)| ∧ circumCircle Ω A B C ∧
S.onCircle Ω ∧ |(S─C)| = |(S─B)| ∧ S.sameSide A BC
∧ threePointsOnLine A D E ADE ∧ perpLine ADE BC ∧
D.onLine BS ∧ E.onCircle Ω ∧ threePointsOnLine B E L BE ∧
distinctPointsOnLine D L DL ∧ ¬(BE.intersectsLine DL) ∧
circumCircle ω B D L ∧
P.onCircle Ω ∧ P.onCircle ω ∧ P ≠ B ∧
distinctPointsOnLine B S BS ∧
tangentAtPoint l ω P ∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint l BS X
 → ∠ X:A:B = ∠X:A:C
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with $AB < AC$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of $ABC$. Let $S$ be the midpoint of the arc $CB$ of $\Omega$ containing $A$. The perpendicular from $A$ to $BC$ meets $BS$ at $D$ and meets $\Omega$ again at $E \neq A$. The line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meets line $BE$ at $L$. Denote the circumcircle of triangle $BDL$ by $\omega$. Let $\omega$ meet $\Omega$ again at $P \neq B$. Prove that the line tangent to $\omega$ at $P$ meets line $BS$ on the internal angle bisector of $\angle BAC$.

name: Elements_Prop6
informal_prefix: \/--Prove that if an triangle ABC such that \angle ABC = \angle ACB, then AB=AC.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Prove that if an triangle ABC such that \angle ABC = \angle ACB, then AB=AC.-\/
theorem problem_Elements_Prop6 : ∀ (a b c : Point) (AB BC AC : Line),
  formTriangle a b c AB BC AC ∧ (∠ a:b:c = ∠ a:c:b) →
  |(a─b)| = |(a─c)| :=
by
goal:
∀ (a b c : Point) (AB BC AC : Line),
  formTriangle a b c AB BC AC ∧ (∠ a:b:c = ∠ a:c:b) →
  |(a─b)| = |(a─c)|
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Prove that if an triangle ABC such that \angle ABC = \angle ACB, then AB=AC.

name: Elements_Prop37
informal_prefix: \/--ABC, BCD are two triangles and AD is parallel to BC. C,D are on the same side of AB. Prove that the area of triangle ABC is equal to the area of triangle DBC.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--ABC, BCD are two triangles and AD is parallel to BC. C,D are on the same side of AB. Prove that the area of triangle ABC is equal to the area of triangle DBC.-\/
theorem problem_Elements_Prop37 : ∀ (a b c d : Point) (AB BC AC BD CD AD : Line),
  formTriangle a b c AB BC AC ∧ formTriangle d b c BD BC CD ∧ distinctPointsOnLine a d AD ∧
  ¬(AD.intersectsLine BC) ∧ d.sameSide c AB →
  Triangle.area △ a:b:c = Triangle.area △ d:b:c :=
by
goal:
∀ (a b c d : Point) (AB BC AC BD CD AD : Line),
  formTriangle a b c AB BC AC ∧ formTriangle d b c BD BC CD ∧ distinctPointsOnLine a d AD ∧
  ¬(AD.intersectsLine BC) ∧ d.sameSide c AB →
  Triangle.area △ a:b:c = Triangle.area △ d:b:c
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: ABC, BCD are two triangles and AD is parallel to BC. C,D are on the same side of AB. Prove that the area of triangle ABC is equal to the area of triangle DBC.

name: UniGeo_Quadrilateral1
informal_prefix: \/--In a quadrilateral QRST, QR ⟂ RS , QT ⟂ ST , and ∠ QSR = ∠ SQT.  Prove that ST = QR.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In a quadrilateral QRST, QR ⟂ RS , QT ⟂ ST , and ∠ QSR = ∠ SQT.  Prove that ST = QR.-\/
theorem problem_UniGeo_Quadrilateral1 : ∀ (Q R S T : Point) (QR ST RS QT QS : Line),
  formQuadrilateral Q R T S QR ST QT RS ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine Q S QS ∧
  ∠ Q:R:S = ∟ ∧
  ∠ Q:T:S = ∟ ∧
  ∠ Q:S:R = ∠ S:Q:T →
  |(S─T)| = |(Q─R)| := by
goal:
∀ (Q R S T : Point) (QR ST RS QT QS : Line),
  formQuadrilateral Q R T S QR ST QT RS ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine Q S QS ∧
  ∠ Q:R:S = ∟ ∧
  ∠ Q:T:S = ∟ ∧
  ∠ Q:S:R = ∠ S:Q:T →
  |(S─T)| = |(Q─R)|
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In a quadrilateral QRST, QR ⟂ RS , QT ⟂ ST , and ∠ QSR = ∠ SQT.  Prove that ST = QR.

name: UniGeo_Similarity20
informal_prefix: \/--In triangle HIF, HI ⟂ FI. Given GI ⟂ FH and G is on the line HF, prove that △ F H I ~ △ I H G.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In triangle HIF, HI ⟂ FI. Given GI ⟂ FH and G is on the line HF, prove that △ F H I ~ △ I H G.-\/
theorem problem_UniGeo_Similarity20 : ∀ (F G H I : Point) (FH FI HI GI : Line),
  formTriangle F G I FH GI FI ∧
  formTriangle G H I FH HI GI ∧
  between F G H ∧
  ∠ F:G:I = ∟ ∧ ∠ I:G:H = ∟ ∧
  ∠ H:I:F = ∟ →
  (△ F:H:I).similar (△ I:H:G) :=
by
goal:
∀ (F G H I : Point) (FH FI HI GI : Line),
  formTriangle F G I FH GI FI ∧
  formTriangle G H I FH HI GI ∧
  between F G H ∧
  ∠ F:G:I = ∟ ∧ ∠ I:G:H = ∟ ∧
  ∠ H:I:F = ∟ →
  (△ F:H:I).similar (△ I:H:G)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In triangle HIF, HI ⟂ FI. Given GI ⟂ FH and G is on the line HF, prove that △ F H I ~ △ I H G.

name: UniGeo_Triangle3
informal_prefix: \/--In a triangle HIJ, HI = HJ. K is a point on segment IJ such that \angle IHK = \angle JHK. Prove that \angle HKI = \angle HKJ.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In a triangle HIJ, HI = HJ. K is a point on segment IJ such that \angle IHK = \angle JHK. Prove that \angle HKI = \angle HKJ.-\/
theorem problem_UniGeo_Triangle3 : ∀ (H I J K : Point) (HI IJ JH HK : Line),
  formTriangle H I J HI IJ JH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine H K HK ∧
  IJ.intersectsLine HK ∧ K.onLine IJ ∧ between I K J ∧
  ∠ I:H:K = ∠ J:H:K ∧
  |(H─I)| = |(H─J)| →
  ∠ H:K:I = ∠ H:K:J :=
by
goal:
∀ (H I J K : Point) (HI IJ JH HK : Line),
  formTriangle H I J HI IJ JH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine H K HK ∧
  IJ.intersectsLine HK ∧ K.onLine IJ ∧ between I K J ∧
  ∠ I:H:K = ∠ J:H:K ∧
  |(H─I)| = |(H─J)| →
  ∠ H:K:I = ∠ H:K:J
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In a triangle HIJ, HI = HJ. K is a point on segment IJ such that \angle IHK = \angle JHK. Prove that \angle HKI = \angle HKJ.

name: HP97
informal_prefix: \/--Given that in $\triangle ABC$, $O$ is the circumcenter, and $I$ is the incenter. Line $OI$ is perpendicular to line $AI$. Prove that $AB + AC = 2BC$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Given that in $\triangle ABC$, $O$ is the circumcenter, and $I$ is the incenter. Line $OI$ is perpendicular to line $AI$. Prove that $AB + AC = 2BC$.-\/
theorem problem_HP97 :
  ∀ (A B C O I : Point) (AB BC CA OI AI : Line),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  circumCentre O A B C ∧
  inCentre I A B C ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine O I OI ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine A I AI ∧
  perpLine OI AI
  → (|(A─B)| + |(A─C)|) = (|(B─C)| + |(B─C)|) := by
goal:
∀ (A B C O I : Point) (AB BC CA OI AI : Line),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  circumCentre O A B C ∧
  inCentre I A B C ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine O I OI ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine A I AI ∧
  perpLine OI AI
  → (|(A─B)| + |(A─C)|) = (|(B─C)| + |(B─C)|)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Given that in $\triangle ABC$, $O$ is the circumcenter, and $I$ is the incenter. Line $OI$ is perpendicular to line $AI$. Prove that $AB + AC = 2BC$.

name: HP71
informal_prefix: \/--Given that in $\triangle ABC$, lines $AD$, $BE$, and $CF$ are the altitudes of $\triangle ABC$. Point $H$ is the orthocenter of $\triangle ABC$, and point $O$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle ABC$. Line $ED$ intersects line $AB$ at point $M$, and line $FD$ intersects line $AC$ at point $N$. Prove that $OH \perp MN$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Given that in $\triangle ABC$, lines $AD$, $BE$, and $CF$ are the altitudes of $\triangle ABC$. Point $H$ is the orthocenter of $\triangle ABC$, and point $O$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle ABC$. Line $ED$ intersects line $AB$ at point $M$, and line $FD$ intersects line $AC$ at point $N$. Prove that $OH \perp MN$.-\/
theorem problem_HP71 :
  ∀ (A B C D E F H O M N : Point)
    (AB BC CA AD BE CF ED FD MN OH: Line),
    formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine A D AD ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine B E BE ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine C F CF ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint BC AD D ∧ perpLine BC AD ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint CA BE E ∧ perpLine CA BE ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CF F ∧ perpLine AB CF ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AD BE H ∧ H.onLine CF ∧
    circumCentre O A B C ∧
    orthoCentre H A B C ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine D E ED ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine F D FD ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint ED AB M ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint FD AC N ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine O H OH ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine M N MN
  → perpLine OH MN
:= by
goal:
∀ (A B C D E F H O M N : Point)
    (AB BC CA AD BE CF ED FD MN OH: Line),
    formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine A D AD ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine B E BE ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine C F CF ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint BC AD D ∧ perpLine BC AD ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint CA BE E ∧ perpLine CA BE ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CF F ∧ perpLine AB CF ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AD BE H ∧ H.onLine CF ∧
    circumCentre O A B C ∧
    orthoCentre H A B C ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine D E ED ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine F D FD ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint ED AB M ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint FD AC N ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine O H OH ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine M N MN
  → perpLine OH MN
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Given that in $\triangle ABC$, lines $AD$, $BE$, and $CF$ are the altitudes of $\triangle ABC$. Point $H$ is the orthocenter of $\triangle ABC$, and point $O$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle ABC$. Line $ED$ intersects line $AB$ at point $M$, and line $FD$ intersects line $AC$ at point $N$. Prove that $OH \perp MN$.

name: MP97
informal_prefix: \/--In $\triangle ABC$, points $D$ and $E$ are on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively, such that $BD = CE$. Lines $BE$ and $CD$ intersect at point $O$, and $OD = OE$. Prove that $AB = AC$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In $\triangle ABC$, points $D$ and $E$ are on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively, such that $BD = CE$. Lines $BE$ and $CD$ intersect at point $O$, and $OD = OE$. Prove that $AB = AC$.-\/
theorem problem_MP97 :
∀ (A B C D E F G : Point) (AB BC CD DA AC AD EF : Line),
  (formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA)
  ∧ (∠B:A:D = ∠A:D:C)
  ∧ (E.onLine BC)
  ∧ (between B E C)
  ∧ (|(B─E)| = |(A─B)|)
  ∧ (|(C─E)| = |(C─D)|)
  ∧ (¬(EF.intersectsLine AB))
  ∧ distinctPointsOnLine E F EF
  ∧ distinctPointsOnLine A C AC
  ∧ (twoLinesIntersectAtPoint EF AC G)
  ∧ (twoLinesIntersectAtPoint EF AD F)
  → (|(E─G)| = |(G─F)|)
:= by
goal:
∀ (A B C D E F G : Point) (AB BC CD DA AC AD EF : Line),
  (formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA)
  ∧ (∠B:A:D = ∠A:D:C)
  ∧ (E.onLine BC)
  ∧ (between B E C)
  ∧ (|(B─E)| = |(A─B)|)
  ∧ (|(C─E)| = |(C─D)|)
  ∧ (¬(EF.intersectsLine AB))
  ∧ distinctPointsOnLine E F EF
  ∧ distinctPointsOnLine A C AC
  ∧ (twoLinesIntersectAtPoint EF AC G)
  ∧ (twoLinesIntersectAtPoint EF AD F)
  → (|(E─G)| = |(G─F)|)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In $\triangle ABC$, points $D$ and $E$ are on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively, such that $BD = CE$. Lines $BE$ and $CD$ intersect at point $O$, and $OD = OE$. Prove that $AB = AC$.

name: MP19
informal_prefix: \/--In quadrilateral $ABCD$, $AE \perp BD$ at point $E$, $CF \perp BD$ at point $F$, and point $P$ is the midpoint of $AC$. Prove that $PE = PF$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In quadrilateral $ABCD$, $AE \perp BD$ at point $E$, $CF \perp BD$ at point $F$, and point $P$ is the midpoint of $AC$. Prove that $PE = PF$.-\/
theorem problem_MP19 :
∀ (A B C D E F P : Point)
  (AB BC CD DA BD AE CF AC : Line),
  formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine B D BD ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine A E AE ∧
  E.onLine BD ∧
  perpLine AE BD ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine C F CF ∧
  twoLinesIntersectAtPoint CF BD F ∧
  perpLine CF BD ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine A C AC ∧
  midpoint A P C
→ |(P─E)| = |(P─F)| :=
by
goal:
∀ (A B C D E F P : Point)
  (AB BC CD DA BD AE CF AC : Line),
  formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine B D BD ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine A E AE ∧
  E.onLine BD ∧
  perpLine AE BD ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine C F CF ∧
  twoLinesIntersectAtPoint CF BD F ∧
  perpLine CF BD ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine A C AC ∧
  midpoint A P C
→ |(P─E)| = |(P─F)|
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In quadrilateral $ABCD$, $AE \perp BD$ at point $E$, $CF \perp BD$ at point $F$, and point $P$ is the midpoint of $AC$. Prove that $PE = PF$.

name: CO20
informal_prefix: \/--As shown in the figure, in an isosceles triangle $ABC$ with $AB = BC$, $I$ is the incenter, $M$ is the midpoint of $BI$, $P$ is a point on side $AC$ such that $AP = 3PC$, and $PI$ is extended to a point $H$ such that $MH \perp PH$. $Q$ is the midpoint of $AB$ on the circumcircle of $\triangle ABC$. Prove: $BH \perp QH$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--As shown in the figure, in an isosceles triangle $ABC$ with $AB = BC$, $I$ is the incenter, $M$ is the midpoint of $BI$, $P$ is a point on side $AC$ such that $AP = 3PC$, and $PI$ is extended to a point $H$ such that $MH \perp PH$. $Q$ is the midpoint of $AB$ on the circumcircle of $\triangle ABC$. Prove: $BH \perp QH$.-\/
theorem problem_CO20 :
∀ (A B C I M P H Q : Point) (AB BC CA PH MH BH QH: Line),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  |(A─B)| = |(B─C)| ∧
  inCentre I A B C ∧
  midpoint B M I ∧
  between A P C  ∧
  (|(A─P)| = 3 * |(P─C)|) ∧
  between P I H ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine P H PH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine M H MH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine B H BH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine Q H QH ∧
  perpLine PH MH ∧
  cyclic Q B C A ∧
  |(A─Q)| = |(B─Q)|
  → perpLine BH QH :=
by
goal:
∀ (A B C I M P H Q : Point) (AB BC CA PH MH BH QH: Line),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  |(A─B)| = |(B─C)| ∧
  inCentre I A B C ∧
  midpoint B M I ∧
  between A P C  ∧
  (|(A─P)| = 3 * |(P─C)|) ∧
  between P I H ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine P H PH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine M H MH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine B H BH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine Q H QH ∧
  perpLine PH MH ∧
  cyclic Q B C A ∧
  |(A─Q)| = |(B─Q)|
  → perpLine BH QH
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: As shown in the figure, in an isosceles triangle $ABC$ with $AB = BC$, $I$ is the incenter, $M$ is the midpoint of $BI$, $P$ is a point on side $AC$ such that $AP = 3PC$, and $PI$ is extended to a point $H$ such that $MH \perp PH$. $Q$ is the midpoint of $AB$ on the circumcircle of $\triangle ABC$. Prove: $BH \perp QH$.

name: CO19
informal_prefix: \/--As shown in the figure, in an acute-angled triangle $ABC$, $M$ is the midpoint of side $BC$, and point $P$ lies on side $AB$ such that $AP$ bisects $\angle BAC$. The line $MP$ intersects the excircles of $\triangle ABP$ and $\triangle ACP$ at points $D$ and $E$, respectively. Prove: If $DE = MP$, then $BC = 2BP$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--As shown in the figure, in an acute-angled triangle $ABC$, $M$ is the midpoint of side $BC$, and point $P$ lies on side $AB$ such that $AP$ bisects $\angle BAC$. The line $MP$ intersects the excircles of $\triangle ABP$ and $\triangle ACP$ at points $D$ and $E$, respectively. Prove: If $DE = MP$, then $BC = 2BP$.-\/
theorem problem_CO19 :
  ∀ (A B C M P D E : Point) (AB BC CA AP MP : Line) (ω₁ ω₂ : Circle),
  formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  midpoint M B C ∧
  insideTriangle P A B C AB BC CA ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine A P AP ∧
  ∠B:A:P=∠C:A:P ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine M P MP ∧
  circumCircle ω₁ A B P ∧
  circumCircle ω₂ A C P ∧
  D.onLine MP ∧ D.onCircle ω₁ ∧
  E.onLine MP ∧ E.onCircle ω₂ ∧
  |(D─E)| = |(M─P)|
  → (|(B─C)| = 2 * |(B─P)|) := by
goal:
∀ (A B C M P D E : Point) (AB BC CA AP MP : Line) (ω₁ ω₂ : Circle),
  formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  midpoint M B C ∧
  insideTriangle P A B C AB BC CA ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine A P AP ∧
  ∠B:A:P=∠C:A:P ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine M P MP ∧
  circumCircle ω₁ A B P ∧
  circumCircle ω₂ A C P ∧
  D.onLine MP ∧ D.onCircle ω₁ ∧
  E.onLine MP ∧ E.onCircle ω₂ ∧
  |(D─E)| = |(M─P)|
  → (|(B─C)| = 2 * |(B─P)|)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: As shown in the figure, in an acute-angled triangle $ABC$, $M$ is the midpoint of side $BC$, and point $P$ lies on side $AB$ such that $AP$ bisects $\angle BAC$. The line $MP$ intersects the excircles of $\triangle ABP$ and $\triangle ACP$ at points $D$ and $E$, respectively. Prove: If $DE = MP$, then $BC = 2BP$.

name: MP9
informal_prefix: \/--In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle A = 3\angle C$ and $BC = 2AB$. Prove that $\angle BAC = 90^\circ$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle A = 3\angle C$ and $BC = 2AB$. Prove that $\angle BAC = 90^\circ$.-\/
theorem problem_MP97 :
∀ (A B C D E F G : Point) (AB BC CD DA AC AD EF : Line),
  (formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA)
  ∧ (∠B:A:D = ∠A:D:C)
  ∧ (E.onLine BC)
  ∧ (between B E C)
  ∧ (|(B─E)| = |(A─B)|)
  ∧ (|(C─E)| = |(C─D)|)
  ∧ (¬(EF.intersectsLine AB))
  ∧ distinctPointsOnLine E F EF
  ∧ distinctPointsOnLine A C AC
  ∧ (twoLinesIntersectAtPoint EF AC G)
  ∧ (twoLinesIntersectAtPoint EF AD F)
  → (|(E─G)| = |(G─F)|)
:= by
goal:
∀ (A B C D E F G : Point) (AB BC CD DA AC AD EF : Line),
  (formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA)
  ∧ (∠B:A:D = ∠A:D:C)
  ∧ (E.onLine BC)
  ∧ (between B E C)
  ∧ (|(B─E)| = |(A─B)|)
  ∧ (|(C─E)| = |(C─D)|)
  ∧ (¬(EF.intersectsLine AB))
  ∧ distinctPointsOnLine E F EF
  ∧ distinctPointsOnLine A C AC
  ∧ (twoLinesIntersectAtPoint EF AC G)
  ∧ (twoLinesIntersectAtPoint EF AD F)
  → (|(E─G)| = |(G─F)|)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In $\triangle ABC$, $\angle A = 3\angle C$ and $BC = 2AB$. Prove that $\angle BAC = 90^\circ$.

name: MP75
informal_prefix: \/--In convex quadrilateral $ABCD$, diagonals $AC$ and $BD$ intersect at point $O$, $AB + AC = DB + DC$, and $OB > OC$. Prove that $OA > OD$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In convex quadrilateral $ABCD$, diagonals $AC$ and $BD$ intersect at point $O$, $AB + AC = DB + DC$, and $OB > OC$. Prove that $OA > OD$.-\/
theorem problem_MP75 :
  ∀ (A B C D O : Point) (AB BC CD DA AC BD : Line),
    formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine A C AC ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine B D BD ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AC BD O ∧
    (|(A─B)| + |(A─C)| = |(D─B)| + |(D─C)|) ∧
    (|(O─B)| > |(O─C)|)
  → (|(O─A)| > |(O─D)|) := by
goal:
∀ (A B C D O : Point) (AB BC CD DA AC BD : Line),
    formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine A C AC ∧
    distinctPointsOnLine B D BD ∧
    twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AC BD O ∧
    (|(A─B)| + |(A─C)| = |(D─B)| + |(D─C)|) ∧
    (|(O─B)| > |(O─C)|)
  → (|(O─A)| > |(O─D)|)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In convex quadrilateral $ABCD$, diagonals $AC$ and $BD$ intersect at point $O$, $AB + AC = DB + DC$, and $OB > OC$. Prove that $OA > OD$.

name: MP12
informal_prefix: \/--In $\triangle ABC$, $AB = AC$, $\angle A = 20^\circ$, and the angle bisector of $\angle ABC$ intersects $AC$ at point $D$. Prove that $AD = BD + BC$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In $\triangle ABC$, $AB = AC$, $\angle A = 20^\circ$, and the angle bisector of $\angle ABC$ intersects $AC$ at point $D$. Prove that $AD = BD + BC$.-\/
theorem problem_MP12 :
∀ (A B C D : Point) (AB BC CA : Line),
  (formTriangle A B C AB BC CA)
  ∧ (|(A─B)| = |(A─C)|)
  ∧ (∠B:A:C = 2/9 * ∟)
  ∧ D.onLine CA
  ∧ between A D C
  ∧ (∠A:B:D = ∠D:B:C)
  → |(A─D)| = (|(B─D)| + |(B─C)|)
:= by
goal:
∀ (A B C D : Point) (AB BC CA : Line),
  (formTriangle A B C AB BC CA)
  ∧ (|(A─B)| = |(A─C)|)
  ∧ (∠B:A:C = 2/9 * ∟)
  ∧ D.onLine CA
  ∧ between A D C
  ∧ (∠A:B:D = ∠D:B:C)
  → |(A─D)| = (|(B─D)| + |(B─C)|)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In $\triangle ABC$, $AB = AC$, $\angle A = 20^\circ$, and the angle bisector of $\angle ABC$ intersects $AC$ at point $D$. Prove that $AD = BD + BC$.

name: MP10
informal_prefix: \/--In $\triangle ABC$, $AB = AC$, and $\angle A = 30^\circ$. Prove that $\triangle ABC$ is an equilateral triangle.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In $\triangle ABC$, $AB = AC$, and $\angle A = 30^\circ$. Prove that $\triangle ABC$ is an equilateral triangle.-\/
theorem problem_MP10 : ∀
(A B C D : Point)
(AB BC CA : Line),
formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
|(A─B)| = |(A─C)| ∧
midpoint A D C ∧
(∠A:B:D * 3= ∟ )
→ (|(A─B)|=|(B─C)| ∧ |(B─C)|=|(C─A)|) := by
goal:
∀
(A B C D : Point)
(AB BC CA : Line),
formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
|(A─B)| = |(A─C)| ∧
midpoint A D C ∧
(∠A:B:D * 3= ∟ )
→ (|(A─B)|=|(B─C)| ∧ |(B─C)|=|(C─A)|)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In $\triangle ABC$, $AB = AC$, and $\angle A = 30^\circ$. Prove that $\triangle ABC$ is an equilateral triangle.

name: CMO24
informal_prefix: \/--In triangle $ ABC $, $ I $ is the incenter, and points $ L, M, N $ are the midpoints of segments $ AI, AC, CI $, respectively. Point $ D $ lies on line segment $ AM $, such that $ BC = BD $. In triangle $ ABD $, the incircle touches $ AD, BD $ at points $ E, F $, respectively. Point $ J $ is the circumcenter of triangle $ AIC $, and $ \omega $ is the circumcircle of triangle $ JMD $. Line $ MN $ intersects $ \omega $ again at point $ Q $. Prove: The lines $ PQ, LN, EF $ are concurrent-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In triangle $ ABC $, $ I $ is the incenter, and points $ L, M, N $ are the midpoints of segments $ AI, AC, CI $, respectively. Point $ D $ lies on line segment $ AM $, such that $ BC = BD $. In triangle $ ABD $, the incircle touches $ AD, BD $ at points $ E, F $, respectively. Point $ J $ is the circumcenter of triangle $ AIC $, and $ \omega $ is the circumcircle of triangle $ JMD $. Line $ MN $ intersects $ \omega $ again at point $ Q $. Prove: The lines $ PQ, LN, EF $ are concurrent-\/
theorem problem_CMO24 :
  ∀ (A B C I L M N D P Q: Point) (AB BC CA AI AC CI AM BD MN JL EF PQ LN: Line),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  inCentre I A B C ∧
  midpoint A L I ∧
  midpoint C M A ∧
  midpoint I N C ∧
  between A D M ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine B D BD ∧
  |(B─C)| = |(B─D)| ∧
  inCircle ω AB CA BD ∧
  tangentAtPoint AC ω E ∧
  tangentAtPoint BD ω F ∧
  circumCentre J A I C ∧
  circumCircle ω J M D ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine M N MN ∧
  P.onLine MN ∧
  P.onCircle ω ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine J L JL ∧
  Q.onLine JL ∧
  Q.onCircle ω ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine E F EF ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine L N LN ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine P Q PQ
  → concurrent PQ LN EF := by
goal:
∀ (A B C I L M N D P Q: Point) (AB BC CA AI AC CI AM BD MN JL EF PQ LN: Line),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  inCentre I A B C ∧
  midpoint A L I ∧
  midpoint C M A ∧
  midpoint I N C ∧
  between A D M ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine B D BD ∧
  |(B─C)| = |(B─D)| ∧
  inCircle ω AB CA BD ∧
  tangentAtPoint AC ω E ∧
  tangentAtPoint BD ω F ∧
  circumCentre J A I C ∧
  circumCircle ω J M D ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine M N MN ∧
  P.onLine MN ∧
  P.onCircle ω ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine J L JL ∧
  Q.onLine JL ∧
  Q.onCircle ω ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine E F EF ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine L N LN ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine P Q PQ
  → concurrent PQ LN EF
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In triangle $ ABC $, $ I $ is the incenter, and points $ L, M, N $ are the midpoints of segments $ AI, AC, CI $, respectively. Point $ D $ lies on line segment $ AM $, such that $ BC = BD $. In triangle $ ABD $, the incircle touches $ AD, BD $ at points $ E, F $, respectively. Point $ J $ is the circumcenter of triangle $ AIC $, and $ \omega $ is the circumcircle of triangle $ JMD $. Line $ MN $ intersects $ \omega $ again at point $ Q $. Prove: The lines $ PQ, LN, EF $ are concurrent

name: HP13
informal_prefix: \/--Given that in $\triangle ABC$, points $D$ and $E$ lie on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively, such that $DE \parallel BC$. Lines $BE$ and $CD$ intersect at point $F$. The circumcircle of $\triangle BDF$ is $\odot O$, and the circumcircle of $\triangle CEF$ is $\odot P$. These two circles intersect at point $G$. Prove that $\angle BAF = \angle CAG$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Given that in $\triangle ABC$, points $D$ and $E$ lie on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively, such that $DE \parallel BC$. Lines $BE$ and $CD$ intersect at point $F$. The circumcircle of $\triangle BDF$ is $\odot O$, and the circumcircle of $\triangle CEF$ is $\odot P$. These two circles intersect at point $G$. Prove that $\angle BAF = \angle CAG$.-\/
theorem problem_HP13 :
  ∀ (A B C D E F G : Point) (AB BC CA DE BE CD : Line) (O P : Circle),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  D.onLine AB ∧ between A D B ∧
  E.onLine AC ∧ between A E C ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine D E DE ∧
  ¬(DE.intersectsLine BC) ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine B E BE ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine C D CD ∧
  twoLinesIntersectAtPoint BE CD F ∧
  circumCircle O B D F ∧
  circumCircle P C E F ∧
  G.onCircle O ∧
  G.onCircle P ∧ G ≠ F
  → ∠B:A:F = ∠C:A:G
:= by
goal:
∀ (A B C D E F G : Point) (AB BC CA DE BE CD : Line) (O P : Circle),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  D.onLine AB ∧ between A D B ∧
  E.onLine AC ∧ between A E C ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine D E DE ∧
  ¬(DE.intersectsLine BC) ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine B E BE ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine C D CD ∧
  twoLinesIntersectAtPoint BE CD F ∧
  circumCircle O B D F ∧
  circumCircle P C E F ∧
  G.onCircle O ∧
  G.onCircle P ∧ G ≠ F
  → ∠B:A:F = ∠C:A:G
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Given that in $\triangle ABC$, points $D$ and $E$ lie on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively, such that $DE \parallel BC$. Lines $BE$ and $CD$ intersect at point $F$. The circumcircle of $\triangle BDF$ is $\odot O$, and the circumcircle of $\triangle CEF$ is $\odot P$. These two circles intersect at point $G$. Prove that $\angle BAF = \angle CAG$.

name: MP35
informal_prefix: \/--In convex quadrilateral $ABCD$, $BC = CD$, $\angle ADB = 30^\circ$, and $\angle ABD - \angle DBC = 60^\circ$. Find $\angle CAD$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In convex quadrilateral $ABCD$, $BC = CD$, $\angle ADB = 30^\circ$, and $\angle ABD - \angle DBC = 60^\circ$. Find $\angle CAD$.-\/
theorem problem_MP35 : ∀
  (A B C D : Point)
  (AB BC CD DA : Line),
  formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
  |(B─C)| = |(C─D)| ∧
  ∠A:D:B = 1/3 * ∟ ∧
  ∠A:B:D = ∠D:B:C + 2/3 * ∟
  → ∠C:A:D = 1/3 * ∟ := by
goal:
∀
  (A B C D : Point)
  (AB BC CD DA : Line),
  formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
  |(B─C)| = |(C─D)| ∧
  ∠A:D:B = 1/3 * ∟ ∧
  ∠A:B:D = ∠D:B:C + 2/3 * ∟
  → ∠C:A:D = 1/3 * ∟
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In convex quadrilateral $ABCD$, $BC = CD$, $\angle ADB = 30^\circ$, and $\angle ABD - \angle DBC = 60^\circ$. Find $\angle CAD$.

name: MP22
informal_prefix: \/--In equilateral triangle $\triangle ABC$, point $D$ is on side $AB$, and point $E$ is on the extension of $CB$ such that $AD = BE$. Prove that $CD = ED$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--In equilateral triangle $\triangle ABC$, point $D$ is on side $AB$, and point $E$ is on the extension of $CB$ such that $AD = BE$. Prove that $CD = ED$.-\/
theorem problem_MP22 :
∀ (A B C D E : Point) (AB BC CA : Line),
  (formTriangle A B C AB BC CA)
  ∧ (|(A─B)| = |(B─C)|)
  ∧ (|(B─C)| = |(C─A)|)
  ∧ between A D B
  ∧ between C B E
  ∧ (|(A─D)| = |(B─E)|)
  → (|(C─D)| = |(E─D)|) := by
goal:
∀ (A B C D E : Point) (AB BC CA : Line),
  (formTriangle A B C AB BC CA)
  ∧ (|(A─B)| = |(B─C)|)
  ∧ (|(B─C)| = |(C─A)|)
  ∧ between A D B
  ∧ between C B E
  ∧ (|(A─D)| = |(B─E)|)
  → (|(C─D)| = |(E─D)|)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: In equilateral triangle $\triangle ABC$, point $D$ is on side $AB$, and point $E$ is on the extension of $CB$ such that $AD = BE$. Prove that $CD = ED$.

name: HP23
informal_prefix: \/--Given that $O$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle ABC$, and points $D$ and $E$ lie on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively. Line $OF$ is perpendicular to line $DE$ at point $F$. Points $L$, $M$, and $N$ are the midpoints of line segments $DE$, $BE$, and $CD$, respectively. Prove that points $F$, $L$, $M$, and $N$ are concyclic.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem

\/--Given that $O$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle ABC$, and points $D$ and $E$ lie on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively. Line $OF$ is perpendicular to line $DE$ at point $F$. Points $L$, $M$, and $N$ are the midpoints of line segments $DE$, $BE$, and $CD$, respectively. Prove that points $F$, $L$, $M$, and $N$ are concyclic.-\/
theorem problem_HP23 :
∀ (A B C O D E F L M N : Point) (AB BC CA DE OF : Line),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  circumCentre O A B C ∧
  between A D B ∧
  between A E C ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine D E DE ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine O F OF ∧
  twoLinesIntersectAtPoint OF DE F ∧
  perpLine OF DE ∧
  midpoint D L E ∧
  midpoint B M E ∧
  midpoint C N D
  → cyclic F L M N
:= by
goal:
∀ (A B C O D E F L M N : Point) (AB BC CA DE OF : Line),
  formTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
  circumCentre O A B C ∧
  between A D B ∧
  between A E C ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine D E DE ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine O F OF ∧
  twoLinesIntersectAtPoint OF DE F ∧
  perpLine OF DE ∧
  midpoint D L E ∧
  midpoint B M E ∧
  midpoint C N D
  → cyclic F L M N
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
import UniGeo.Theorem
natural_language: Given that $O$ is the circumcenter of $\triangle ABC$, and points $D$ and $E$ lie on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively. Line $OF$ is perpendicular to line $DE$ at point $F$. Points $L$, $M$, and $N$ are the midpoints of line segments $DE$, $BE$, and $CD$, respectively. Prove that points $F$, $L$, $M$, and $N$ are concyclic.
